Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 08:14AM Joyce4123 wrote: My daughter had a crainotomy in November and had less than desireable results.  Her recent MRI didn't show any new lesions but shows considerable swelling which is being treated (still) with decadron (the dreaded good/evil drug).  She is HER2+ . She also had WBR a year and a half ago and also had SRS surgery last April   I do believe each person is completely different in the way they react to all of these treatments of the brain.  She has tried Tykerb and Tramodol w/no success.  There are so many things doctors can do now and as I said each person reacts differently to those treatments so you could definitely be one of those who has great results!  I hope for all the best for you and that you continue the fight.  Joyce
Posts.Title: Ugh! Brain Mets are Back! Rohm dellmonica

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 12:28PM - edited Oct 10, 2010 12:36PM by Joyce4123 Hi - FMLA act ensures the qualified employee's job is held for up to 12 weeks.  The leave can be with or without pay depending on the company policy.  The company MUST hold the employee's job for the 12 weeks unless the position is eliminated.  After 12 weeks it is up to the company to determine if they wish to keep the job open for the employee or not.  At the end of 12 weeks they must offer you the option of COBRA.  On another note, if you are married and your spouse has insurance, you should get on his coverage asap (many companies hold open enrollment late November into December for a January 1st coverage. Almost all companies accept spouses and children with or without preexisting conditions.  Also, if you do not have a spouse who has insurance  take the COBRA and when that ends be sure to obtain other insurance within 60 days of the end of your COBRA.  You can not be denied coverage due to preexisting conditions if you make certain obtain a Certificate of Portability from your current carrier when your COBRA coverage ends..  If you want more info just PM me.  I wish you all the very best! Joyce
Posts.Title: FMLA question chk8 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 03:49PM Joyce4123 wrote: FMLA is only for 12 weeks in a 52 week period.  If you are making up your time then you are not on FMLA.  Having said that if your employer has changed their ruling on FMLA, then you may be required to use it.  It is up to the employer whether or not they force the employee to use their paid time off in conjunction with the FMLA leave.  If you work 1250 hours in a year after having used all of your 12 weeks of leave time then it renews again in the next year.  HOWEVER the company decides if their "year" is a calendar year or a floating year from the time you begin your leave.  Most employers require the employee to use their paid time off in conjunction with the 12 weeks of leave.  If the employee doesn't have 12 weeks of paid time off accumulated, the employee's job must still be held for the 12 weeks.  The 12 weeks can be consecutive or intermittent such as you mention having to take the leave for doctor appointments.  First thing you need to do however is to get clarification, in writing, what the company policy is on FMLA leave.  You should have been given that policy at some point.  PM me if you need further info an my best to you Joyce
Posts.Title: FMLA tmwalls20623 Joyce4123

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 01:34AM Joyce4123 wrote: Jellydonut - yes the doctor needs to fill out forms.  Go to your human resources department and request the FMLA leave paperwork.  HOWEVER, your employer must employ I believe it is 25 or more employees within a 75 mile radius (if they have more than one location) to be required to offer FMLA.  The dr. forms are in that paperwork.  My best to you joyce

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 05:07PM Joyce4123 wrote: I would keep working as long as you are healthy enough to do so.  Then there is the Family and Medical Leave Act you can apply for at work if you qualify for it.  It gives you 12 weeks off work w/o fear of losing your job and they must continue to pay their share of your health insurance and you must continue to pay your share as well.  Meanwhile check into the other things suggested above so that in the event you become unable to work you will be prepared.  If they put you on decardon or dexamethasone (same thing) get off of it as soon as possible as there are a ton of side effects from it esp. long term.  I am sorry that you have to deal with all of this but keep the faith and fight hard for the best results.  My best to you Joyce

Posts.Title: Nothing more they can do .... Joyce4123 kayfh

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 08:11PM Joyce4123 wrote: Good for you!  I wanted to share an experience my daughter has just had with medication.  She has mets to the liver (stable and treating with Herceptin) and brain.  She was given a med called Keppra which is an anti-seizure med about 5-6 weeks ago b/c her surgeon thought she may have had a seizure.  She became weaker and weaker and weaker along with many other issues.  We thought it was from her WRB and SRS surgery and she hung in there  hoping it would get better.  Now here's the good news - we looked up the side effects of the Keppra and just about every single one she had!  So she finally called the surgeon and told him of this and he had her get an emergent MRI and saw her yesterday.  He reported the MRI looked great!  All tumors shrinking!  Took her off the Keppra and is having her wean down (again) from the decadron.  My point here is that everyone needs to know what side effects to watch for with their medications.  Her doctor didn't tell her of all the serious ones like suicidal thoughts and double vision, etc.  As she was unable to read the pamphlet (due to double vision) she didn't know of them.  So everyone make sure you know the possible side effects of all your meds so you can be aware.  My best to you all. Joyce

Posts.Title: Now the Brain Leanneh sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 09:35PM Joyce4123 wrote: So sorry to hear of all your problems.  However if your employer has more than 25 employees (I believe it is 25) then you need to request paperwork for the FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE ACT.  This ACT entitles you to 12 weeks of leave (without pay) but without losing your job.  It can be taken consecutively or intermittently as needed.  It is a a federal law and must be offered.  Call your local Legal Aid office or Legal Services office and they may be able to provide you with assistance in getting the leave and also with your mortgage situation.  Good luck and God Bless.

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 08:16PM Joyce4123 wrote: Thanks to you for responding.  Was hoping more sisters would respond but grateful to both of you!  My daughter is doing well right now, thank you.  Just had a CT scan of the liver and no progression was noted.  Next milestone is mri of the brain coming up on 10/18/10 and we are both of course hoping for good results. It is SO difficult, this waiting for testing/scans as I'm sure you both already have experienced.  I truly don't know how you all do it.  What courageous women you are!  Her hair is just beginning to come back in from the WBR and that makes her extremely happy!  She is currently on Avastin and Decadron.  Trying to get the decadron down from 1 mg/day but have had problems.  I'm sure they will try reducing it again.  Thank you for the websites.  I did find good info there and of course am always looking for long term survival stats!  Hell, why not!  I wish the best to you both. Joyce

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 02:40AM Joyce4123 wrote: My advice would be to do everything you can do to avoid dex!  If you can handle the treatments w/o it then please do!  Dex has really bad long term side effects and my daughter has  experienced them first hand.  It can be very dibilitating esp. long term.  If your doc says no then get a second opinion.  My best to you joyce
Posts.Title: Dexamethosone or not? LouiseBogle LouiseBogle

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 08:51AM Joyce4123 wrote: Linda - Regarding going on your husband's insurance - if you have already satisfied your preexisting condition period at your current place of employment you would be given a Certificate of Portability from your current insurance company when you leave.  If you get new insurance (your husband's) in a period of less than 60 days you do not have to meet the preexisting condition clause with his insurance.  The transition should be seamless.  Your HR person should guide you through this.  Just make sure you do this right away so you have no lapse in coverage. Joyce
Posts.Title: Stage IV-How long can we stay NED? ibcmets Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 07:29PM Joyce4123 wrote: Decadron is something you need to get off of as soon as you can!  Google it and you will see tons of long term side effects!  My daughter has been on it for about 1.5 years and is now down to 4 mg a day and we are praying she can get off of it altogether.  It has caused thinning skin with major bruising, weakness in her hips and legs to the point where she is on a walker, a lot of weight gain and of course moon face and other areas of swelling.  This stuff is bad news but much needed for brain mets especially.  So try to get off of it as soon as you can but be sure to wean down SLOWLY to avoid those side effects.  Of course always check with your doctor!  My best to all of you (I'm still praying for a miracle for my daughter). joyce
